関連科目:
Economic History of the European Union、Introduction to European Economic History、
This class is an English version of "EU Keizai-ron" which will be held in the first half of the spring semester. Students who have already taken any credits of "EU Keizai-ron" are basically not allowed to take this class. If you are eager to take this class too, you have to contact SIS office and apply during the course registration period.
授業の概要・背景: The economic integration in the EU has given significant impacts on the world economy, and offers lessons which are also important in considering economic cooperation between Japan and Asian countries. Students will understand not only the EU but also future aspects of the Japanese economy.
授業方法:
The class is held in face to face format.
The class is held by the quarter system (the first half of the autumn semester), on 3rd and 4th slot of Thursday.
If you have any questions, please ask them actively during or after the lecture.

評価.学位授与の方針との関連Relationship to Diploma Polic:
This course is positioned within the curriculum in accordance with the diploma policy and curriculum policy established by the undergraduate/graduate school of International Studies. By proceeding with the study of this course with an awareness of the CP and CP, the following abilities expected by each undergraduate/graduate school will be developed.
European Studies:
1. Understanding and analytical skills regarding international issues: the ability to understand and analyze various regions of the world from different perspectives in the humanities and social sciences.
2. Problem-solving skills: the ability to proactively identify problems and solve them based on appropriate methods.
3. Intercultural understanding and multicultural coexistence: the ability to be sensitive to different cultures and to coexist with diverse cultures.
評価.課題等へのフィードバック方法Methods for Providing Feed: Comments and questions raised by students will be given during the class. Comments on reports will be uploaded on LUNA.

成績評価備考:
備考　Note
After each lecture, students are asked to submit a note on the lecture. The student will be assessed on the basis of his/her participation in the lecture as well as the note (40%). After each class, students are also asked to submit a report based on a theme set by each student (60%).
